text:
I cannot agree here in general.
There are vendors that take it very seriously to *develop* good and full
featured drivers for v4 and Universal Drivers. Don't blame the tech, it's the
vendors. Ironically one of them is Develop (part of Konica Minolta)
https://can01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.develop.de%2F&data=05%7C02%7Cemail_ingestion%40bighatgroup.com%7C311b4377588d40e96dcf08dc282220a0%7C5a01497e1bcb4711b6e6d24f4ab00393%7C0%7C0%7C638429374245059794%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C0%7C%7C%7C&sdata=haYbkpXDeW4t6WHd0KzjmTQnSogbfXVdBGhGvkrsbAY%3D&reserved=0
Best regards, Karl Wester-Ebbinghaus Senior IT Consultant Microsoft MVP – Azure
Hybrid & Migrate / Windows Server -----Ursprüngliche Nachricht----- Von:
 Im Auftrag von Melvin Backus Gesendet:
Mittwoch, 7. Februar 2024 16:55 An:  Betreff:
RE: [patchmanagement] 
"Universal" drivers have always been problematic regarding feature completeness.
That's made particularly painful with the specific printer was chosen over
competing units entirely because of a feature that is only available in a unit
specific driver. -- There are 10 kinds of people in the world... those who
understand binary and those who don't. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

metadata.topic: RE: A Practical Guide to PrintNightmare in 2024
